loans.name: Gbenonkpo Group

texts.fr: GBENONKPO est un groupe de six personnes, dont les membres résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe, Edwige, âgée de 47 ans, est mariée à Césaire, un menuisier. Edwige a un peu fréquenté. Le couple a cinq enfants tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Edwige et son mari vivent ensemble avec leurs enfants et assurent ensemble les différentes charges de la maison. Il y a près de dix neuf ans que Edwige vend des volailles et des noix de palme dans un marché du Bénin. Edwige exerce cette activité passionnément, ce qui lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Edwige s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle, Edwige sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe GBENONKPO, un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Ce crédit leur servira à mieux répondre aux demandes de leur clientèle et à se faire plus de profits. Les crédits antérieurement reçus ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en: The "Gbenonkpo" group comprises six people who all live in the same area. The group leader, Edwige, is 47 years old and married to Césaire, a carpenter. Edwige has a little bit of schooling. The couple have five children, all in school and in the care of their parents. Edwige and her husband live together with their children and provide for the household together. For close to ten years, Edwige has sold poultry and palm nuts at a market in Benin. She runs this business with passion, which has allowed her to provide for her needs and those of her children. Edwige gets her supplies at a market in Benin. With the goal of satisfying her clientele, Edwige is seeking a third loan with ALIDÉ, together with the other members of the Gbenonkpo group. This loan will serve to better respond to the needs of their customers and generate higher profits. All the previous loans were repaid properly.

loans.use: To buy chickens and palm nuts.

loans.name: Ruthy

texts.en:
Ruthy works hard to support her family. She is married and has had a food vending business in the Philippines for the past 14 years.

Ruthy has requested a 12,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business. In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva is a 37-year-old married woman and the mother of two teenage children. She is from Talibon, Bohol and has run a sari-sari or variety store business from her home for more than 10 years. This is the source of her income. Eva works hard to earn a living so that she can support her husband in meeting their family's needs especially for her children's schooling.

Eva is asking for a loan from CEVI to buy merchandise like canned goods, snack food, biscuits, soap and toiletries to sell. With this, she will be able to increase her stocks thus allowing her to cater for more customers and buyers in her store.

In the future, Eva dreams of improving her business so that it will continue to generate the necessary revenue for their needs and expenses.

loans.use: to buy merchandise like canned goods, snack food, biscuits, soap and toiletries to sell

loans.name: Isidra

texts.en:
Isidra is 62 years old and married with eight children.

Isidra works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15000 loan through NWTF to buy inventory to sell like sugar, coffee, egg, and spices, etc.

Isidra has borrowed and repaid 22 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 13 years and also earns an income from farming sugarcane.

Isidra aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy grocery inventory to sell like sugar, coffee, egg, and spices, etc.

loans.name: Dieu Est Grand Group

texts.fr: Le groupe DIEU EST GRAND est formé de trois personnes qui habitent dans la même maison. La représentante de ce groupe, nommée Colette Titiola, est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. Colette Titiola est âgée de 53 ans. Colette Titiola est une veuve et mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés et à sa charge. Colette Titiola vit seule avec ses enfants et assure seule leurs divers besoins. Colette Titiola a peu fréquenté. Il y a près de seize années que Colette Titiola exerce comme activité, la vente des produits vivriers (maïs, igname) à son domicile et par le système de distribution. Cette activité lui permet de répondre sans grande difficulté aux besoins de sa famille. Dans le souci de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle, Colette Titiola désire renforcer son activité. Pour ce faire, Colette Titiola sollicite, ensemble avec les autres membres du groupement DIEU EST GRAND, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Ce crédit leur permettra à rehausser le niveau de leurs activité et à se faire plus de profits.
texts.en: The "Dieu est Grand" group comprises three people who live in the same house. The leader of the group, named Colette Titiola, is the woman whose hand is raised in the photo. Colette Titiola is 53 years old. She is a widow and has four children, all in school and in her care. Colette Titiola lives alone with her children and provides for them by herself. She has had a little bit of schooling. For close to 16 years, Colette Titiola has run a business selling various food items (maize, yams) at her home and through the distribution system. This business allows her to meet the needs of her family without too much difficulty. With the hope of better responding to her customers' needs, Colette Titiola wants to strengthen her business. She is seeking a loan with ALIDÉ together with the other members of the Dieu est Grand group. This loan will allow them to raise the level of their businesses and earn more profits.

loans.use: To buy yams, bags of maize, and various items.

loans.name: Wangnignigbe Group

texts.fr: WANGNIGNIGBE est un groupe de sept personnes, dont les membres résident dans la même région. La représentante du groupe, Antoinette est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. Antoinette est âgée de 33 ans et est mariée à un certain Thimotée. Antoinette n’a pas fréquenté.le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisé et à leur charge. Le couple vit ensemble avec leurs enfants et assurent ensemble les différentes charges de la maison. Antoinette vend des vivres (maïs, riz, condiments et huiles) à son domicile. Il y a près de quatre ans que Antoinette exerce cette activité. Antoinette s’approvisionne dans une région du Bénin. Cette activité lui permet de subvenir sans grande difficulté, à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Antoinette et les autres membres du groupe WANGNIGNIGBE sollicitent pour une troisième fois, l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue d’augmenter leur stock et de renforcer leur fonds de roulement et de mieux répondre aux exigences de leur clientèle. Les crédits antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en: The "Wangnignigbe" group comprises seven people who all live in the same area. The group leader, Antoinette, has her hand raised in the photo. Antoinette is 33 years old and married to a man named Thimotée. Antoinette did not attend school, and the couple have three children, all in school and in the care of their parents. The couple live together with their children and provide for the household together. Antoinette sells basic food items (maize, rice, condiments, and oils) at her home. She has run this business for close to four years. Antoinette gets her supplies in a region of Benin. This business allows her to meet her needs and those of her children without too much difficulty. Antoinette and the other members of the Wangnignigbe group are seeking financial support from ALIDÉ for the third time, with the goal of increasing their stock, strengthening their working capital, and responding better to the needs of their clientele. All the previous loans were repaid properly.

loans.use: To buy maize, condiments, rice, and oils.

loans.name: Vivogbe Group

texts.fr: VIVOGBE est un groupe de quatre personnes, dont les membres exercent des activités génératrices de revenus dans un même environnement. La représentante du groupe, Léontine Akouavi est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. Léontine Akouavi est âgée de 41 ans et est mariée à un certain Prosper. Léontine Akouavi n’a pas fréquenté. Le couple a un enfant scolarisé et à leur charge. Le couple vit ensemble avec leur enfant et assurent ensemble les différentes charges du foyer. Il y a près de dix huit ans que Léontine Akouavi vend des plastiques et des oignons dans un marché du Bénin. Léontine Akouavi s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin.  Cette activité lui permet de subvenir sans grande difficulté, à ses besoins et à ceux de son enfant. Léontine Akouavi et les autres membres du groupe VIVOGBE sollicitent pour une troisième fois, l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue de renforcer leur fonds de roulement et leur activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de leur clientèle. Les deux crédits précédents ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en: The "Vivogbe" group comprises four people who run businesses in the same area. The group leader, Léontine Akouavi, is the woman whose hand is raised in the photo. Léontine Akouavi is 41 years old and married to a man named Prosper. She did not attend school. The couple have one child, who attends school and is in their care. The couple live together with their child and provide for the household together. For close to 18 years, Léontine AKouavi has sold plastic utensils and onions at a market in Benin. She gets her supplies at a market in Benin. This business allows her to meet her needs and those of her child without too much difficulty. Léontine Akouavi and the other members of the Vivogbe group are seeking financial support from ALIDÉ for the third time, with the goal of strengthening their working capital and better responding to their customers' needs. The two previous loans were repaid properly.

loans.use: To buy plastic utensils and onions.

loans.name: Tohami Group

texts.fr: TOHAMI est un groupe de quatre personnes qui exercent toutes des activités génératrices de revenus. la représentante du groupe, Wassiath est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Wassiath est âgée de 54 ans et est mariée à un certain Moubinou. Wassiath a peu fréquenté. Le couple a cinq enfants tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Wassiath et son mari vivent ensemble avec leurs enfants et assurent ensemble les différentes charges de la maison. Il y a près de quatre ans que Wassiath vend les produits divers à son domicile. Wassiath exerce cette activité passionnément, ce qui lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Wassiath s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle, Wassiath sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe TOHAMI, un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Ce crédit leur servira à mieux répondre aux demandes de leur clientèle et à se faire plus de profits. Les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en: The "Tohami" group comprises four people who all run income-generating activities. The group leader, Wassiath, is the woman whose hand is raised in the photo. Wassiath is 54 years old and married to a man named Moubinou. Wassiath has had a little bit of schooling. The couple have five children, all in school and in the care of their parents. Wassiath and her husband live together with their children and provide for the household together. For close to four years, Wassiath has sold various items at her home. She runs this business passionately, which allows her to meet her needs and those of her children. Wassiath gets her supplies at a market in Benin. With the goal of satisfying her customers, Wassiath is seeking a third loan with ALIDÉ, along with the other members of the Tohami group. This loan will allow them to better respond to their customers' needs and earn higher profits. All the previous loans were repaid properly.

loans.use: To buy various items.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Sawe Rahayu Indah Group

texts.en: To continue her plan, Ni Komang needs to borrow a new loan. This loan will be used to purchase feed for the piglets that will be born soon and also to renovate the barn. She can’t wait to see the sow give birth to the piglets. Ni Komang hopes the sow continues to be healthy and that she can give birth safely. She plans to sell the piglets after keeping them for two months. To reduce the cost of feed, she will give them a mixed feed. With support from the vet and the loan officer, she is optimistic that the business will succeed.

loans.use: to purchase feed and renovate the barn

loans.name: Soledad

texts.en:
Soledad, aged 57, is a resident of Intramuros, Manila, Philippines. She is single and manages her house while operating her business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.   

Soledad sells newspapers. She also has a variety store, a small convenience store which sells groceries, toiletries and beverages.  It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg.  Her regular customers are neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operatiing her business, Soledad is requesting a 14,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy newspapers, grocery products and toiletries. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Soledad hopes that her business will continue to be successful and dreams of having a good life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies there.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for newspapers, grocery products and toiletries needed in her business.

loans.name: Emeliana

texts.en:
Emeliana works hard to support her family. Emeliana is married and has a dried-fish-selling business in the Philippines.

Emeliana requested a loan of PHP 10000 through NWTF to buy more stocks of dried fish to sell.

Emeliana has been in this business for 8 years now.

In the future Emeliana would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of dried fish to sell.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is a 33-year-old married man and operates a tricycle transport business. He has been in this business for more than five years, and this is the source of his income. Samuel is asking for a loan to buy fuel for the tricycle and to pay for its repairs. With this, he will be able to maintain the good working condition of the tricycle.

Samuel aims to improve his business and plans on exploring another venture to augment his income. Moreover, he wants to continue sending his children to school for their education and so they can have a bright future.

loans.use: to buy fuel for the tricycle and to pay for its repairs

loans.name: Gerelmaa

texts.en:
Gerelmaa is 28 years old. She lives with her mother and her daughter in small house in the Arhangai province of Mongolia. Her mother takes care of her daughter Asral, who is one-year-old. Gerelmaa is the only working person of her family and her income is the only income of family. She used to work as saleswoman in local market. 

She is now requesting a 5'000'000 MNT loan to import consumer goods from South Korea and to open her retail business in local market. Customers' perspective of Korean goods is high and the estimated income would be enough to cover the family's expenses. She is planning to save excess money for her daughter's future.

loans.use: to import consumer goods from South Korea and to open her retail business in local market

loans.name: Gbedokpo Group

texts.fr: Le groupe GBEDOKPO est formé de trois personnes qui habitent dans le même quartier. La représentante de ce groupe, nommée Bernadette, est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. Bernadette est âgée de 42 ans et est  mariée à Désiré, un commerçant. Le couple a sept enfants, dont certains scolarisés et tous à leur charge. Le couple vit ensemble avec leurs enfants et assurent ensemble les diverses charges du foyer. Bernadette n’a pas fréquenté. Il y a près de dix neuf ans que Bernadette exerce comme activité, la vente de moutons dans son quartier ; ce qui lui permet de répondre sans grande difficulté aux besoins de sa famille. Dans le souci de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle, Bernadette désire renforcer son activité. Pour ce faire, Bernadette sollicite, ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe GBEDOKPO, un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Le prêt antérieur a été bien remboursé.
texts.en:
The Gbedokpo group is made up of three people who live in the same area. The representative of this group, named Bernadette, is the one whose hand is raised in the photo. 

Bernadette is 42 years old and is married to a man named Désiré, a merchant. The couple has seven children, who are all still under their care. Some of the children have been to school. The couple lives together with their children and together they take care of the different household expenses. Bernadette has not been school.

It has been almost 19 years that Bernadette has been selling sheep in her area. This allows her to meet the needs of her family without much difficulty. In order to better respond to the needs of her customers, Bernadette wants to increase her business. To do this, Bernadette is asking, along with the other members of the Gbedokpo group, for a second loan through Alidé. Their previous loan has been fully repaid.

loans.use: to buy sheep and corn

loans.name: Erdenebaatar

texts.en:
Erdenebaatar is a 44-year-old man who lives with his wife and two sons in a house in Dornod Province, Mongolia. His wife, Ichinhorloo, aged 45, works as a saleswoman at the local market. His sons, Davaahuu and Davaadorj, aged 18 and 16, are university students. 

Erdenebaatar has also been working as a salesperson in the local market for years and now he is planning to start his own clothing retail business there. He is a welcoming and communicative person who says "I and my wife had built close relationships with customers and suppliers within the province so it will be easy for us to run our own business". He is requesting a loan of 2,590,000 MNT loan to import clothes for his new business.

loans.use: to import clothes for his new clothing retail business

loans.name: Enhjargal

texts.en:
Enhjargal is 50 years old and lives with her son in a ger in Darhan Province, Mongolia. Her son, Monhzul, aged 30, works for a private company. She has been operating her grocery store business from a rental counter in the local market since 1992. 

Enhjargal stopped her grocery store business temporarily due to the lack of working capital and investment. She has about 20 years of experience in the business but the reason her working capital and investment decreased to the point that she had to temporarily stop her business was that her husband sold their house and land, took all the money and went away. 

Enhjargal is now requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to purchase inventory and restart her grocery store business in the local market. She is a hard-working, healthy and responsible woman.

loans.use: to purchase inventory and restart her grocery store business in the local market

loans.name: Leonisa

texts.en:
Leonisa is 57 years old, and is married with three children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Leonisa has had a business selling bread in the Philippines for the past four years.

Leonisa has requested a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more bread to sell to customers. In the future, she would like to build and expand her business to support her family's financial stability.

loans.use: to purchase more bread to sell to customers.

loans.name: Enhjargalan

texts.en:
Enhjargalan is the 43-year-old female head of her family who lives with her two children in a rental apartment in Govisumber Province, Mongolia. Her daughter, Uyanga, aged 20, is a university student and her son, Ayanga, aged 17 is a polytechnic college student. 

Enhjargalan has been working as a saleswoman at the local market since 2007. She has built a strong customer and supplier base within the province and now she is planning to open her own grocery store in that market. She is requesting a loan of 1,100,000 MNT to pay for inventory and the first month's counter rent. She is a neat, responsible and hard-working woman.

loans.use: to pay for inventory and the first month's counter rent for her new grocery store business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 41 years old. She is blessed with two children. She has been running a retail shop as a primary business and mixed crop farming as a secondary business for the past eight years with the monthly income of KES. 10,000 which she uses to support her family. 

She is applying for her third loan term from KADET LTD after repaying the previous loan successfully. Mary will use the loan to buy seedlings and fertilizer and to restock her retail shop. 


With the anticipated profit from the business she will buy more stock for her retail shop. Her hopes and dreams are to educate her children up to university level and expand the farming business.

loans.use: to buy seedlings and fertilizer and to restock her retail shop.

loans.name: Juweiria

texts.en:
Juweiria is a hard-working woman and a very good and wise entrepreneur, who has shown great skills in proper business management in the way she used her previous loan capital. She is very sure that she will do the same with this new investment, should the opportunity be granted to her. 

Juweiria says that the last loan was of great help to her. With this new loan, she will buy coconuts, cassava, and sweet potatoes for her new business. She says that she is still in her tailoring business as well, and she earns good income with both businesses. She thanks you in advance for your kindness.

loans.use: to buy coconuts, cassava, and sweet potatoes for a new business selling fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Patronella

texts.en:
Patronella is a single woman. She has one child. She describes herself to be an honest, disciplined and trustworthy woman. 

She operates a retail business where she sells clothes. Her business is located at a potential business area and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate access to clean water. 

Patronella will use the KES 15,600 loan to buy a water tank, which will be used by her five family members for storing clean water for household chores and drinking. 

Her business goal is to expand her business within five years. She hopes that in the future she will improve the living standard of her family, as she is the sole provider for her family.

loans.use: to buy  a water tank

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy materials for her business which makes and sells costume jewelry

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a rice retailing business in the Philippines. She is borrowing 10,500 Philippines pesos (PHP) through NWTF to buy additional sacks of rice to sell.

Juliet has been in this business for two years, and earns additional income from raising pigs. She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts, with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional sacks of rice to sell

loans.name: Ndegwa

texts.en:
Ndegwa is 38 years old. He is married, has five children, and lives with his family in Samburu, Coast province. Ndegwa describes himself as a hard-working and honest person.

Ndegwa works with his wife in their store. He has been working since he was a young boy with the help of his parents. This has made him very responsible towards his family. In addition to this, he owns a motorcycle for transport services. He will use this current loan to stock his store with food and other products so that he can increase his sales. He has customers who are requesting certain products from him that he doesn't have. This investment is very important because it will enable him to improve his income.

Ndegwa's dream is to be able to increase his business and watch his children grow up well with a good education.

loans.use: to stock his store with foodstuffs and other products

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is 30 years old, married to Grace, and has been blessed with two children. He is a mechanic and has been running his business for the past seven years. His monthly income is KES 18,000.

He is servicing his first loan of KES. 20,000 from KADET LTD, and this will assist him to purchase more motor vehicle spare parts and associated items. He plans to use the anticipated profits to reinvest and increase his inventory. 

His future dream is to have a stable business and income that will help him to improve the living standards of his family.

loans.use: to purchase car spare parts.

loans.name: Carolyne

texts.en:
Carolyne is 29 years old, married, and has one child. She owns a retail shop and has been in business for four years. She also earns an income from farming, and she is very hard-working. Since she joined Faulu Kenya her business has grown, and she is now able to serve her customers well.

She hopes to expand her business more. She requires a loan of 21,363.75 KES to increase her stock of sugar, beans, wheat flour and maize flour.

loans.use: to buy sugar, beans, wheat flour, and maize flour to resell in her retail shop.

loans.name: Thoa

texts.en:
Thoa is 41 years old and has two children, who are studying at high school and college. She and her husband sell beverages to earn a living and have done this work for 17 years. Her family’s total earnings are about 6,000,000 Vietnamese dong (VND) per month. 

Thoa began participating in SEDA's credit program earlier this year. In the last cycle she borrowed 5,152,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow the same amount of money to buy beer, soft drinks and tea to sell. She plans to use the profits she earns to bring up her children well.

loans.use: to buy beer, soft drinks and tea to sell.

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta is 29 years old and married with three children. She has two children in school. Julieta works very hard to provide for them. Julieta runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 15000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell like can goods, sugar, coffee, etc.
Julieta has been in this business for one year. In the future, Julieta would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell in her general store

loans.name: Juan Antonio

texts.es: Juan Antonio de 30 años de edad reside junto a su esposa y sus dos pequeños hijos, es un hombre muy trabajador que siempre su mayor sueño ha sido entregarle un mejor futuro a su familia, es muy conocido por sus vecinos por ser entregado al trabajo ya que es el único que genera ingresos económicos en su hogar, y es el que se encarga de llevar el pan de cada día. Desde hace tiempo se dedica a la pesca artesanal, todas las mañanas despierta con entusiasmo y sale con lancha a extraer el fruto de una laguna cercana a su lugar de residencia. Se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar a INTEGRAL un crédito para la compra de materiales para reparar su lancha ya que por el uso se ha desgastado y quisiera mejorarla, desea comprar: pinturas, lijas y madera. Agradece a las personas de buen corazón que pronto le ayudaran y espera saldar la deuda lo antes posible.
texts.en:
Juan Antonio is 30 years of age and resides with his wife and two small children. He is a very hardworking man who has always dreamed of providing a better future for his family. He is well known among his neighbors for being devoted to his work since he is the only one generating income for his household and taking on the responsibility of providing for its daily sustenance. Some time ago he began earning a living as a fisherman using traditional methods. Every morning he wakes up enthusiastically and goes out on a boat to harvest the fruit of a lake near to his place of residence. 

He finds he needs to request a loan from Apoyo Integral for purchasing materials to repair his boat since it is worn with use and he would like to make improvements. He wishes to buy paint, sandpaper and wood. He appreciates the good-hearted people who will be helping him soon and expects to pay off the debt as soon as possible.

loans.use: to purchase paint, sandpaper and wood.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
This is Nenita, who is a 68-year-old resident of Intramuros, Manila, Philippines. She is married to Renato and is a mother to her children.  She and her husband manage their household while operating their business. At this time, she works hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.   

Nenita has a retailing business, where she sells different products such as scissors, knives, cutters and other products of the like. She also sells some vegetables.  Her regular customers are her neighbours and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting for a Php14, 000 loan. She will be utilizing this loan to buy additional stock of products like knives, scissors, cutters and other products. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Nenita hopes that her business will continue to be successful and dreams that her grandchildren will complete their studies. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional stock of products like knife, scissor, cutter and other products needed in her business.

loans.name: Trinidad

texts.en: Trinidad is a 60-year-old married woman. She lives in Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur in the Philippines with her three children. She has been running a general store at home for 4 years, which gives her a monthly income of PHP 10,000. Sustaining her business is important, so she has applied for a loan of PHP 50,000 from GDMPC to purchase new items such as candies, milo, shampoo, soaps etc. She joined GDMPC in 2011. Trinidad hopes for more sales and plans to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase new items such as candies, milo, shampoo, soaps etc

loans.name: Luzvisminda

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Luzvisminda works hard to support her family.

She has a fish vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from raising pigs.  Luzvisminda is borrowing PHP 18000 through NWTF to buy fish for her fish vending business.

Luzvisminda has been sustaining her business activities through her past 7 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her to attain her dream of saving money for expanding her business.

loans.use: to buy fish for her fish vending business

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Lolita works hard to support her family. She has a business buying and selling rice grains in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from raising pigs. Lolita is borrowing PHP 16000 through NWTF to buy additional sacks of rice grains to sell.
Lolita has been sustaining her business activities through her past 4 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her to attain her dream of repairing and renovating her family home.

loans.use: to buy additional sacks of rice grains to sell

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 67 years old and lives in Lopoc, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte. She is married with 9 children.
Erlinda owns a fishing business, where she catches and sells fish for a living. She has been doing this business for 6 years. She has requested a loan for additional capital.
Erlinda has been a member of PMPC for 2 years. In the future, Erlinda hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: for fishing financing

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
As a married parent of nine children, Maria works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and earns additional income from pig fattening. Maria is borrowing PHP 10000 through NWTF to purchase additional stocks to sell like rice, canned goods, spices, etc. for her general store business.

Maria has been sustaining her business activities through her past 10 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough and provide a secure future for her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks to sell like rice, canned goods, spices, etc.

loans.name: Simbira Group

texts.fr: La cliente Mapendo, est une femme dynamique du groupe de credit  Simbira.  Agée de 32ans, est  mere de 4 enfants  tous  scolarisés. Elle vend des fretins depuis son bas âge. Elle sollicite ce credit pour cette même fin dont elle veut s’approvisionner en 100 kg des fretins. Elle souhaite avoir un dépôt dans l’avenir et ainsi elle remercie Hekima pour ces prêts et prie Dieu de le bénir d’avantage.
texts.en:
Mapendo, age 32, is a dynamic woman and member of the group Simbira. She has four children who all attend school. She started selling small fish at a young age. 

She is requesting this new loan to buy 100 kg of small fish. In the long term, she plans to own a depot.  

Mapendo thanks Hekima for the loans she has received, and she prays for God’s blessing.

loans.use: to buy 100 kg of small fish.

loans.name: Bernabe

texts.en: Bernabe, a 37-year-old fisherman from Talibon, Bohoh, has been in the business for almost 10 years now. Bernabe is requesting a loan to buy new fishing nets, lead weights, buckets and fuel for the boat. These purchases will enable him to improve his catch and sell more fish to the market, thereby increasing his income.

loans.use: to buy new fishing nets, lead weights, buckets and fuel for the boat.

loans.name: Rufo

texts.en: Rufo is an active member of PMPC. He is a 47-years-old widower with 5 adult children. He lives in Caticugan, Squijor, Siquijor. Rufo is engaged in fishing. He has been doing this for 30 years as a main source of his family's daily livelihood, with a monthly income of PHP 6,000. Rufo has requested a loan from PMPC amounting to PHP 14,900 to purchase additional fishing materials. He hopes to catch more fish using these new fishing materials and provide for the daily needs of his family.

loans.use: To purchase additional fishing materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more dried fish, spices and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Alberta

texts.en:
Alberta, a 63-year-old widowed mother of three living in Aurora, Zambo del Sur, Philippines, has been operating her own retail store at home for seven years now. Every month, she earns PHP 3,000.

A member of GDMPC since 2011, Alberta is requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 to purchase additional products such as canned goods, noodles, sugar and coffee. She plans to repair the store's native roof and expand her business area.

loans.use: to purchase additional products such as canned goods, noodles, sugar and coffee.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en: Alma is an active member of PMPC under micro-finance. She lives in Lico-an, Maria, Siquijor. She is married with 3 school-aged children and 1 infant-aged child. Alma is engaged in hog raising. She has been in this business for 2 years, with an average monthly income of PHP 4,000. She wants to take another loan from PMPC in the amount of PHP 6,000 to purchase additional piglets. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to sustain her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets

loans.name: Manolita

texts.en:
Manolita is married with three children.  Manolita is 75 years old and lives in Dullan, Aloran Misamis Occidental.  

Manolita sells foods to earn a living and has had this business for six years.  She has requested a loan to be used for her rice field inputs.  

Manolita has been a member of PMPC for six years.  In the future, Manolita hopes to have more savings.

loans.use: to use for her rice field inputs.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is 36 years old and married with five children.  

Mercy works hard to provide for her family.  She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 22,000 Philippine Peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell like sugar, milk, canned goods, etc. 

Mercy has borrowed and repaid 22 loans from NWTF before this loan.  She has been running the general store for 13 years and also earns an income from raising livestock.  

Mercy aspires to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: To buy additional items to sell like sugar, milk, canned goods, etc.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia is 50 years old and separated, with three children. She is from Bayabas, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. Lucia owns and operates a coconut production business to earn a living. She has been in this business for 15 years and she earns 10,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) per month. 

In 2007, Lucia joined GDMPC. She is requesting a loan of 40,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizer. Lucia hopes to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Soledad

texts.en:
Soledad is married with five children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Soledad is 52 years old and has two children who are in school.

Soledad has a general store business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase stock to sell in her general store like soap, shampoo, noodles, cream, etc.

Soledad has been in this business for 12 years. In the future, Soledad would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock to sell in her general store like soap, shampoo, noodles, cream, etc.

loans.name: Sharon

texts.en:
People are always looking to better themselves; it doesn't matter when they do it because the goal is to get ahead and build a more prosperous future, which is the case with this young single lady. She has great skills, is honest, hardworking and enterprising. She lives alone in a rental house.

For some time, she has had a small stall where she sells a variety of clothing for men, women and children such as shirts, blouses, dresses, trousers and others. She does business every day and is well known and preferred by the people in the area, thanks to the way she serves them as well as her product quality and good prices.

She wants to buy more merchandise, but does not have enough capital to do so, which is why she is requesting a loan for the purchase of wholesale clothing in different styles and sizes.

loans.use: to purchase wholesale clothing in different styles and sizes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Tita

texts.en:
Tita is 33 years old and married with one child.

Tita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock to sell in her general store like eggs, soap, noodles, toothpaste, etc.

Tita has borrowed and repaid 9 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 5 years and also earns an income from fish vending.

Tita aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell in her general store like eggs, soap, noodles, toothpaste, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy goats and sheep for animal-selling business

loans.name: Nonvigbe Group

texts.fr: Le groupe NONVIGBE est formé de trois personnes qui habitent dans le même quartier. La représentante de ce groupe, nommée Léa, âgée de 38 ans, est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. Léa est mariée à un chauffeur du nom de Julien. Le couple a trois enfants, dont certains scolarisés et tous à leur charge. Léa, et Julien vivent ensemble avec leurs enfants et assurent ensemble les différentes charges de la maison. Léa n’a pas fréquenté. Il y a près de quatre ans que Léa exerce comme activité, la vente des produits vivriers à son domicile ; ce qui lui permet de répondre sans grande difficulté aux besoins de sa famille. Dans le souci de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle, Léa désire renforcer son activité. Pour ce faire, Léa sollicite, ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe NONVIGBE, un premier crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
The NONVIGBE group consists of three people who live in the same neighborhood. The group’s representative is Lea, seen with her hand raised in the photo. Lea, age 38, is married to a driver named Julien. The couple have three dependent children, some of whom go to school. Lea and Julien live together with their children, and the couple handle the various household responsibilities together. 

Lea never went to school. She started to sell food products from her home nearly four years ago. This activity allows her to provide fairly well for her family’s needs. 

To achieve customer satisfaction, Lea wishes to bolster her activity. To that end, she is seeking a first loan from ALIDé together with the other members of the group NONVIGBE.

loans.use: to buy food products for resale.

loans.name: Tambuka Group

texts.fr:
Odette  fait partie du groupe  Tambuka et habite à Gitega. Elle a 33 ans et mariée à  Faustin, un maçon. Ensemble ils ont 5 enfants, dont le cadet étudie en 2e Année  primaire et l’aîné en 8e Année.

Elle fait le commerce de bière depuis  4 ans. 

Elle est à son neuvième  crédit à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’elle obtient, elle  va  augmenter son capital et acheter  beaucoup de casiers de bière à revendre pour gagner plus.

Le gain de son commerce lui a permis  d’acheter une vache et il contribue dans la scolarisation des enfants et dans l’achat de leurs habits.
texts.en:
Odette lives in Gitega and is a member of the Tambuka group. She is 33 years old and married to a mason named Faustin. Odette and Faustin have five children, the youngest of whom is in the second year of primary school, and the eldest of whom is in the eighth year of schooling.

Odette has been selling beer for four years now.

She is on her ninth loan from Turame. With the KIVA loan that she obtains, she will increase her capital and buy lots of cases of beer to resell in order to earn more money.

The profits from her business have allowed her to buy a cow and they also enable her to buy clothing for her children and pay for her children's schooling.

loans.use: to increase her capital and buy lots of cases of beer to resell in order to earn more money

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma, age 30, is married and has three young children.  She lives in a community in the town of Msambweni.  

Six years ago Fatuma decided to establish her fish selling business.  She sells her goodies from home and she is well known in the neighborhood.  

She has currently requested a loan of 15,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES). She plans to use it to buy more stock of fish and cooking oil.  

Her goal is to be able to open a kiosk.  This way she will manage to have financial stability.

loans.use: to buy more stock of fish and cooking oil.

loans.name: Mina

texts.en:
Mina is 40 years old.  She is married and has one child, aged 12.  In 2000, she established  her poultry farming business.  Working 7 days a week and 4 hours a day, she suports her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid three loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buy small chickens for her business.  

In the future, Mina plans to uplift the economic condition of her family.  She thanks you for your support. 

In the Kathmandu Valley, raising poultry for eggs and meat is a very profitable business.  Kiva loans are used to purchase chicks, food, and necessary medicine to keep the chickens healthy.  Once matured, the chickens are sold at small butcher shops or in the many open air markets throughout the valley.

loans.use: to buy young chickens

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en: Mwanasha has shown great responsibility in managing her business. She is taking out a new loan to make some improvements in her 'makuti' (thatching materials made from palm fronds) sales business. In addition, thanks to the profits she has acquired; she has been able to include coconut-selling to improve her income. Mwanasha is asking for this new loan to buy more 'makuti' and coconuts to sell.

loans.use: to buy more 'makuti' and coconuts to sell.

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora is a 58-year-old married woman from Talibon, Bohol.  She sells vegetables and sea products like fish, clamps and others.

Leonora is asking for a loan to buy more vegetables to sell in her store.

In the future, Leonora hopes to expand her business and explore other ventures to increase her income.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables to sell in her store

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines.

She is borrowing 19,500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) through NWTF to purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle.

Rowena has been in this business for 2 years.  Rowena earns more income from farming sugarcane.

Rowena has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF.  She dreams to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Vevencia

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Vevencia works hard to support her family.

She has a furniture making business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from raising pigs.  Vevencia is borrowing 29,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) through NWTF to purchase additional materials for her furniture making business.

Vevencia has been sustaining her business activities through her past 22 loans from NWTF.  She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials for her furniture business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase livestock for resale.

loans.name: Dil Kumari

texts.en:
Dil Kumari is 55 years old.  She is married and has 3 children aged 32, 25 and 20.  In 2001, she established her poultry farming business.  Working 7 days a week and 4 hours a day, she supports her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid 4 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buy small chickens for her business.

In the future, Dil Kumari plans to improve the economic conditions of her family.  She thanks you for your support.

In the Kathmandu Valley, raising poultry for eggs and meat is a very profitable business.  Kiva loans are used to purchase chicks, food, and necessary medicine to keep the chickens healthy.  Once matured, the chickens are sold at small butcher shops or in the many open-air markets throughout the valley.

loans.use: to buy chickens

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma works hard to support her family.  She is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

Wilma requested a 10,000 Philippine Peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy additional materials for the repair of her fishing boat.

Wilma has been in this business for 15 years now.

In the future, Wilma would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional materials for the repair of her fishing boat

loans.name: Zanmankou Group

texts.fr: ZANMANKOU est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres exercent des activités génératrices de revenus dans un même environnement. La représentante du groupe, Reine est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. Reine est âgée de 33 ans et est mariée à Charles, un mécanicien. Reine n’a pas fréquenté. Le couple a deux enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Le couple vit ensemble avec leurs enfants et assure ensemble les différentes charges de la maison. Reine vend des mèches et des produits cosmétiques dans son atelier au Bénin. Reine s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Cette activité lui permet de subvenir sans grande difficulté, à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Reine et les autres membres du groupe ZANMANKOU sollicitent pour une première fois, l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue de renforcer leur fonds de roulement et leur activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de leur clientèle.
texts.en:
The ZANMANKOU group consists of three members who work at the same location. The group’s representative is Reine, seen with her hand raised in the photo. Reine, age 33, is married to a mechanic named Charles. The couple have two dependent children who both go to school. Reine and Charles live together with their children, and the couple handle the various household responsibilities together. 

Reine never went to school. She sells hair extensions and cosmetic products at her shop in Benin. She buys her stock at a market in Benin. This activity allows her to provide fairly well for her family’s needs. 

To bolster their working capital and to achieve customer satisfaction, Reine and the other members of the group ZANMANKOU are seeking a first loan from ALIDé.

loans.use: to buy hair extensions and cosmetic products for resale.

loans.name: Mwanatumu

texts.en:
Mwanatumu, age 45, is married and has three children.  She lives with them in a suburban neighborhood in Msambweni.

She has been generating her own income for three years.  She set up a food stall selling a variety of dishes and beverages.

Mwanatumu wants to buy more furniture in her stall to provide a conducive environment to her customers.  Therefore, she has decided to request a loan of 25,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES) from Yehu to make this investment.

Her goal is to continue working with loans in order to get income and to make improvements to her house.

loans.use: to buy more furniture for her stall

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is 46 years old and married.

Evelyn raises pigs in the Philippines.  She requested a 28,000 Philippine Peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Evelyn has been raising pigs for 6 years now, and has borrowed 16 times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Evelyn would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Sanu

texts.en:
Sanu is 36 years old.  She is married and has 3 children aged 19, 13 and 7.  In 2004, she established her tea shop business.  Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, she supports her family.

She has already received and successfully repaid 4 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buy food materials for her business.  In the future, Sanu plans to improve the financial condition of her family.  She thanks you for your support.

Whether on the streets of Kathmandu or in the villages outside of the capital, tea shops are places of business and meeting in Nepal.  Called a chiya pasal, these tea shops make a sweet, milky tea that can be purchased for a few cents a cup.  With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to keep their store shelves stocked while increasing their profit margins by buying in greater volume.

loans.use: to buy food materials for her business

loans.name: Linh

texts.en: Linh, 40, is single.  She lives with her family in Ho Chi Minh City.  Linh supports her family by running a general store in front of her house.  She started this business fifteen years ago.  She is requesting a loan to expand her business by buying a greater variety of products, in particular softdrinks and and snack foods, to stock her store and better satisfy her customers.  She hopes her business runs smoothly and will generate a higher income to assist her in improving her family's living conditions and set aside some money for facing difficulty in the future.

loans.use: To buy a greater variety of products, in particular softdrinks and and snack foods to stock her store

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy groceries for her grocery store

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Judith is 55 years old, married, and has five children.  She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 25000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell in her general store, such as bread, canned goods, soft drinks, etc. Judith has borrowed and paid back 21 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 15 years and also earns an income from farming sugarcane. Judith aspires to build and expand her business in order to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell in her general store, such as bread, can goods, soft drinks, etc.

loans.name: Pramila

texts.en:
Pramila is 38 years old.  She is married and has one child, aged 3.  In 2000, she established her vegetable farming business.  Working 7 days a week and 4 hours a day, she supoorts her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid 3 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buy seed and fertilizer.  

In the future, Pramila plans to improve the financial condition of her family.  She thanks you for your support.

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural.  Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land.  Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet.  With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer.  With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market.  Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year.

loans.use: to buys seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Asad

texts.en:
Sixty-two-year-old Asad lives in Marneuli District with his wife and son. Asad has requested loans from local financial institutions several times for family business start-ups, but with no success, his requests consistently rejected because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions.

The only source of family income is agricultural activities, including their two cows whose milk is used in cheese production. Asad owns 0.7 hectare of land upon which he grows alfalfa. He also has a greenhouse and sows tomatoes and cucumbers. According to Credo estimates, the family belongs to the subsistence poor category.

Asad's loan request from Credo was approved within the frame of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup loans with soft conditions to the country's rural poor, who do not have access to credit products since they are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. With the loan, Asad will build a new greenhouse which will enable him to grow more vegetables and thus increase the income of the family. This new business initiative will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to build a greenhouse and sow tomatoes and cucumbers.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is 34, a farmer in Nkubu county in Kenya where she lives with her husband and two children who are both schooling. She has been in farming for the past 7 years producing milk, tea, maize, beans and vegetables which she sells to the people in her local area. High costs of feeds and low rainfall are her major challenges in farming.

She is requesting a 40,000 KES loan from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase materials for constructing a zero-grazing unit which will help her in feeding her dairy cows and hence she will get more milk and more income from selling the milk and be able to better her livelihood and pay school fees for her children.

Christine is so grateful to Juhudi Kilimo for it's faster way of processing the loans.

loans.use: To purchase materials for constructing a zero-grazing unit

loans.name: Librada

texts.en:
Librada is 52 years old and widowed with three children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 15,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell like canned goods, soft drinks, eggs, etc..

Librada has borrowed and paid 4 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 5 years and also earns an income from raising pigs.

Librada aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell like canned goods, soft drinks, eggs, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more ready-to-wear clothes to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a water tank to use to irrigate his crops.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages to sell in her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Mealii

texts.en:
Mealii is 40 years old.  She is a caring, joyful, responsible, supportive, and determined person.  She lives with her family, her husband and their six children, in the suburban area of Msambweni.  Six years ago, Mealii decided to start a coconut selling business where she sells from her home.

Mealii is an enterprising woman and she dreams of having her own mini-market to increase her income and improve her quality of life.  It is because of this that, little by little, she is increasing the quantity of her product and her sales.  Currently, she is requesting a loan from Yehu that she will invest in the purchase of more coconuts.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of coconuts for sale.

loans.name: Rogelia

texts.en:
As a married parent of eleven children, Rogelia works hard to support her family.

She has a charcoal business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from food vending and selling bananas.  Rogelia is borrowing 14,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell for her charcoal business.

Rogelia has been sustaining her business activities through her past 14 loans from NWTF.  She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Leonardo Robinson

texts.es:
LEONARDO ROBINSON tiene 40 años de edad de estado civil unión libre tiene dos hijos, vive con el conyugue y con los dos hijos en Ventanas Provincia de los ríos. 

Es integrante de la VRC Luchando por una misma causa, se encuentra ubicada en el recinto la primavera, perteneciente al Cantón Ventanas, esta ventanilla se dedica laores agricolas de ciclo corto siembra de maíz, arroz.

LEONARDO ROBINSON se dedica a la Agricultura a la siembra de maíz y fréjol. Solicita el credito para comprar semillas, insumos,fertilizantes, urea. Con la ayuda del crédito podrá aumentar los cultivos y que sean de calidad.

Las compras de los productos lo realizará en ventanas. El sueño es poder es arreglar la casa. Los desafíos a los que se enfrenta es combatir las plagas cómo la paja de burro.
En el tiempo libre le gusta jugar indor.
texts.en:
Leonardo Robinson is 40 years old and has a common-law wife. They live with their two children in Ventanas in the province of Los Ríos. He is a member of the Luchando group which is located in the community of La Primavera, a part of the Ventanas canton.  The branch works with farmers who grow short-cycle crops like corn and rice.

Leonardo Robinson grows corn and beans. He is seeking a loan to buy seeds, supplies, fertilizer, and urea. The money will help him increase production and have quality crops.

He will sell the crops in Ventanas. His dream is to renovate his house. His biggest challenge is overcoming the diseases that attack the crops. In his free time he likes to play indoor sports.

loans.use: to buy supplies such as fertilizer, urea, insecticides and balanced food

loans.name: Habari Njema Group

texts.fr: La cliente Nyambura est trésorière du groupe de crédit Habari Njema. Elle est entrepreneur, mariée et mère de 8 enfants. Son conjoint est vendeur de divers. La cliente vend les denrées alimentaires.  Elle commença avec son fonds propre. Elle vient de réaliser 8 cycles de crédit dans le programme Hekima. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de payer 25 litres d’huile de palmes, 50 litres d’huile de Rina, 50 kg de farine, etc.  La perte de change due à la variation de taux, l’insécurité constituent le défi majeur pour ses activités. La cliente ambitionne scolariser ses enfants. Ainsi,la cliente remercie Hekima pour son soutien aux petits entrepreneurs.
texts.en: The borrower Nyambura is the treasurer of the loan group Nabari Njema.  She is an entrepreneur, married, and the mother of eight children.  Her husband is a vendor of various products.  The borrower sells grocery products.  She started with her own money.  She has completed eight loan cycles with the Hekima program.  This new loan will allow her to buy 25 liters of palm oil, 50 liters of Rina vegetable oil, 50 kg of flour, etc.  The lower exchange rate due to the variation in tax rates and insecurity constitute the main challenges for her business.  The borrower very much wants for her children to be educated.   Therefore, she thanks Hekima for its support of small business owners.

loans.use: to buy 25 liters of palm oil, 50 liters of Rina vegetable oil, 50 kg of flour, etc.

loans.name: Diosa

texts.en:
Diosa is 46 years old, married and has 2 children who are in school.

Diosa is in the agricultural business of pig fattening in the Philippines. She requested a 12,500 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional feeds and vitamins for her pigs. Diosa has been pig fattening for 10 years now, and has borrowed 3 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Diosa would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional feeds and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Gbenan Group

texts.fr: GBENAN est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe, Jeannette est âgée de 41 ans et est mariée à un certain Ambroise. Jeannette n’a pas fréquenté l'école. Le couple a trois enfants tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Jeannette et son mari vivent ensemble avec leurs enfants et assurent ensemble les différentes charges de la maison. Il y a près de quatre ans que Jeannette vend de la nourriture (riz, pâte, haricot,sauce) dans une école de son quartier. Jeannette exerce cette activité passionnément, ce qui lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Jeannette s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle, Jeannette sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe GBENAN, un premier crédit auprès de ALIDé. Ce crédit leur servira à mieux répondre aux demandes de leur clientèle et à se faire plus de profits.
texts.en:
Gbenan is a group of three people, who all live in the same area. The representative of the group, Jeannette, is 41 years old and married to a man named Ambroise. Jeannette has not been to school. The couple has three children, who are all still under their care and who all have been to school. Jeannette and her husband live together with their children and ensure together the different household expenses.

For almost four years now, Jeannette has been selling food (rice, pasta, beans, sauce) in a school in her area. Jeannette does her work passionately, which allows her to meet her and her children's needs. 

Jeannette buys her goods in a market in Benin. In the pursuit of customer satisfaction, Jeannette is requesting, together with the other members of the Gbenan group, this first loan through Alidé. This loan will help them better respond to customer requests and to earn more profits.

loans.use: to buy rice, oil, vandzou [Bambara peas], corn, and condiments

loans.name: Laurent

texts.en:
Laurent is 54 years old and is married with six children between the ages 10 and 26 years old. His business is well organized. He sells eggplant and tomatoes in his market. Laurent has 15 years of experience, with one person to help him. He starts from 7am until 7pm every day.

Laurent has requested a loan from Kiva lender Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business by buying more quantities of tomatoes and eggplant to sell. With this profit, Laurent will reinvest in his business, pay children's school fees and pay medical insurance for his children.

loans.use: To purchase more quantities of tomatoes and eggplant to sell.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is a 36-year-old taxi driver. He has been in the taxi business for the past 3 years, and earns a monthly income of 12,000 KES, which he uses to support his family. He used his previous loan to service his taxi.

James is applying for his fourth loan from KADET LTD after repaying the previous loans successfully. He will use the loan to buy a new motorbike.

He intends to use the anticipated profits to pay his children’s school fees. His dream is to own many cars and motorbikes for hire.

loans.use: to buy a new motorbike.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John, 24 years old, takes care of his three siblings. He operates a clothing stall, where he sells variety of clothes. He has been running the business for three years, earning a monthly income of KES 20,000.

He has received his first loan, of KES 20,000, from KADET LTD, which he intends to use to purchase more clothing for the business. 

The anticipated profit will be used to start a money-transfer business. His dream is to improve his standard of living and help his siblings with their schooling.

loans.use: to purchase clothing for resale.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is 24 years old and lives with her husband and 4-year-old child in a house they rent. She is a hardworking, honest and tenacious person who would like to provide for her family.

Fatuma works alone in a grocery store. She is requesting her first loan from Yehu as she needs to invest in buying foodstuffs, cleaning products, and medicines for her business. Her customers are asking for products that she does not have and so she is losing both sales and customers. The loan will help her to increase her business and her number of customers. This will make her a very good income with which she can support her family.

Fatuma's dream is to own her own premises since she rents the store she sells from.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs, cleaning products, and medicines for her business.

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en:
Flordeliza is 30 years old and married. Flordeliza works very hard to provide for them.

Flordeliza runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 15,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell in her general store like shampoo, canned goods, eggs, noodles, etc.. Flordeliza has been in this business for 3 years.

In the future, Flordeliza would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional stock to sell in her general store like shampoo, canned goods, eggs, noodles, etc.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is married and has 5 children. Mary sells groceries like powered milk, toffees, powered pepper, biscuits and other items at Elmina. She has been in this business for 3 years. Mary uses her income to assist the husband in paying their utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy groceries like milk,  powered milk, canned tomatoes, cooking oil and canned fish to satisfy her customers. Mary hopes to use the new profits to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy groceries like milk, powered milk, canned tomatoes, cooking oil and canned fish to satisfy her customers

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence  is a widow, who has five children. She sells sachet water, which she has done for some years. Florence uses her income to feed and clothe her children, and to pay their school fees. She will use her loan to purchase more sachets of water to resell. With the new profit she will expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more sachets of water to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Edward

texts.en: Edward is a carpenter who makes furniture and other items for sale, which he has done for some years now.  He uses his income to provide food, clothing and shelter for his family. Edward will use his loan to purchase wood, machines and other materials for his work. With the new profit, he will expand his business.

loans.use: purchase  wood, machines and other materials for his work

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria operates this grocery shop in the picture above. She sells groceries like tissue paper, sanitary towels, diapers, powered milk, toffees, biscuits and other items at Cape Coast. She is married and has 4 children. Victoria has been into this business for some years now. She uses her income to  assist the husband in paying their utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy groceries like milk, powered milk, canned tomatoes, cooking oil, canned fish and other varieties of groceries to satisfy her customers. She hopes to use the new profits to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy groceries like milk, powered milk, canned tomatoes, cooking oil, canned fish and other varieties of groceries to satisfy her customers

loans.name: Protais

texts.en: Protais is 32 years old and married with two children, ages 5 and 8 years old. He sells local drinks. Protais has 2 years of experience and he works from 7 am until 6 pm every day of the week. Protais has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to buy more local drinks for resale. With any profits, he will be able to save money for his future and reinvest in his business.

loans.use: To purchase more local drinks to sell.

loans.name: Micheal

texts.en: Micheal  is a cobbler. He repairs shoes and make shoes for sale. Micheal has been doing this for some years. He is married, and has three children. He uses his income to pay his children’s school fees. Micheal will use his loan to purchase equipment, leather and other materials, to use in his work. With the new profit, he will expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase equipment, leather and other materials, for his work as a cobbler.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase irrigation equipment

loans.name: Natividad

texts.en:
Natividad is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling charcoal and bananas in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 20000 Philippine pesos (PHP) through NWTF to buy more charcoal and bananas to sell for her business.

Natividad has been in this business for 8 years. Natividad earns more income from raising livestock.

Natividad has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal and bananas to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks, and beverages

loans.name: Winifred

texts.en: Winifred cooks beans, stew, gari (cassava), and fried plantains to sell at the Cape Coast market, which she has been doing for some years now. She is married with four children. She uses her income to support her husband in the general upkeep of their home. Winifred will use her loan to purchase bags of beans, gari, and plantains to prepare her food to sell. With the anticipated new profits, she wants to operate a chop bar (where a variety of African dishes are sold).

loans.use: purchase bags of beans, gari, and plantains to prepare her food.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret operates the grocery shop shown in the picture above. She sells groceries and household items like tissue paper, sanitary towel, diapers, powdered milk, toffees, biscuits, and more at Cape Coast. She is married and has 4 children. Margaret has been in this business for some years now. She uses her income to assist her husband in paying their utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy milk, powdered milk, canned tomatoes, cooking oil, canned fish, and other varieties of groceries to satisfy her customers' demands. She hopes to use the new profits to expand her business.

loans.use: buy groceries to satisfy her customers' demands

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks, and beverages

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Myrna works hard to support her family.

She has a restaurant business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from general store. Myrna is borrowing PHP 15000 through NWTF to purchase additional ingredients for her restaurant business.

Myrna has been sustaining her business activities through her past 9 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients for her restaurant business

loans.name: Alberta

texts.en: Alberta  is a fish monger. She buys fresh fish from the market and smoke them for sale. Alberta has been selling smoked fish for some years now. She is married. She uses her income to support the husband  to pay their utility and accommodation bills. Alberta  will use her loan to purchase fresh fish to  smoke for sale. Alberta will expand her business with the new profit.

loans.use: purchase fresh fish to smoke for sale.

loans.name: Riziki

texts.en:
Riziki, age 54, is married and has three children between the ages of 9 and 28 years. She lives in a community in the town of Msambweni. She established her grocery store eight years ago. She sells grocery products like rice, sugar, beans, flour, basic grains, over-the-counter medicine, candy, condiments, and cleaning products.

Riziki has requested a loan of 20,000 KES to use it to buy bales of flour, basic grains, detergents, soft drinks, and instant goods. She hopes to increase her clientele and to generate more income. Her goal is to see her business flourish.

loans.use: to buy bales of flour, basic grains, detergents, soft drinks, and instant goods.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba cooks maize and groundnuts together to sell at Akonoba near Cape Coast. In the picture above she is wrapping the maize and groundnuts with corn leaves in a form of packaging. Aba has been in this business for 10 years. She uses her income for the general upkeep of her home. Aba will use her loan to purchase bags of maize and groundnuts for her business. With the new profits she will expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase bags of maize and groundnuts for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for making homemade ice cream

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 54 years old and employed as a teacher and a dairy farmer. She is married to Samuel who is a business man. They are blessed with three children. She has been a teacher as a primary business and dairy farmer as a secondary business for the past twenty years with a monthly income of  20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES).

She is applying for her first loan term with KADET LTD, after being introduced by a KADET LTD staff member.  Grace will use the loan to buy dairy cows and feeds. 

With the anticipated profit from the business she will educate her children. Her hopes and dreams are to own a dairy farm and improve the living standard of her family.

loans.use: to buy dairy cows and feeds.

loans.name: Fati

texts.en: Fati sells palm oil and palm kernel oil at Elmina. She has been in this business for some years now. Fati is married with 3 children. She uses her income to support her husband in the general upkeep of their home. She will use her loan to purchase palm fruit and palm kernel for the extraction of oil to sell. She will expand her business with the anticipated profits.

loans.use: purchase palm fruit and palm kernel for the extraction of oil to sell

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie is 42 years old and married with five children.

Elsie works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 13000 Philippine pesos (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell in her general store like canned goods, soap, noodles, etc..

Elsie has borrowed and paid three loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for three years and also earns an income from food vending.

Elsie aspires to save enough to provide security for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional stock to sell in her general store like canned goods, soap, noodles, etc.

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena produces and sells kenkey (kenkey is an African dish made from maize). She has been in this business for some years. Abana lives with her 3 children at Akonma near Cape Coast  She uses her income to feed and clothe her children. Abana will use her loan to purchase bags of maize for the production of kenkey.  With the new profit, she plans to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase bags of maize for the production of kenkey.

loans.name: Guillerma

texts.en:
As a widowed mother of one child, Guillerma works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from pig-fattening and farming rice businesses.  Guillerma is borrowing 15000 Philippine pesos (PHP) through NWTF to buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell in her sari-sari store.

Guillerma has been sustaining her business activities through her past nine loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her to attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items like snack foods, groceries, etc. to sell in her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Deserose

texts.en: Deserose is 41 years old, married and has five children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines and is requesting a loan for PHP 12,000  through NWTF to buy feed and additional piglets to raise. She has been in this line of work for six years now and has taken out 10 previous loans from NWFT. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and additional piglets to raise

loans.name: Blanca Esther
